Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Working with student scientists to understand global patterns in the present and future ecological consequences of ants
Award.AbstractNarration:
Understanding the distribution of species and the processes they mediate is a major focus of ecology. Yet no studies model the consequences of ecologically important animal groups across the globe. In part, the difficulty stems from the fact that the best-studied groups globally (i.e., birds, mammals), are also among the most difficult ones to study in terms of their ecological effects. Because dominant insect groups such as ants have large, direct ecological effects, processes mediated by insects are easier to study. But studies of these effects have been limited by the lack of global data on insect assemblages, geographic ranges and diversity patterns. Taking advantage of a global network of collaborators and a student scientist outreach program, the proposed work will investigate the climatic drivers of the diversity and abundance of different functional groups of ants (e.g., predators, herbivores or generalist foragers) at global and local scales and develop global models of rates and dynamics of the impact of ants based on field data. These impacts will include predation, nectar and other sugar consumption, seed consumption, and seed dispersal by ants. It will then examine whether changes in temperature, due to experimental warming in outdoor arrays, influence ant functional effects as expected based on global models. Finally, a synthetic model of global patterns in ecological functions mediated by ants will be developed and used to project changes in those functions under climate change scenarios. This proposed research program tests these and other scenarios and then uses the results of the tests to develop synthetic models of the effects of ant communities (and changes in ant communities) on plant and animal communities both today and in the context of global change.

Course modules will be developed for 7-12th graders in the US (in schools predominately serving minorities) and around the world that teach participants about climate change, insects, and biogeography. All learning modules will be made available online so that any student scientist that wishes can participate in the project. In addition, this project will involve undergraduate, graduate students and postdocs in every component, including interactions with the younger students. All data will be posted on our existing 'global ants' website (http://www.antmacroecology.org/) and permanently archived in the Harvard Forest Archives (http://harvardforest.fas.harvard.edu).

POR.DRECONTENT:
With their small mouths but massive numbers ants carry out many tasks of benefit to human societies. These include physical tasks such as turning over soil, dispersing seeds (the carpets of wildflowers in many regions depend on the efforts of ants), consuming pests, and, as our work has recently shown, cleaning up garbage and other waste in cities. In addition, ants increasingly serve as models from which we learn and borrow, whether as we search for new antibiotics, new ways to design social networks or new approaches to industrial design.

 We sought to understand what determines which ants live where and their consequences, good or bad. Working with collaborators around the world we generated the first global models of the number of kinds of ants in a region, the number likely to be found locally, the abundance of ants and, most recently, even the sizes of ants. These models allowed us to predict how the ants found in different regions will likely change with global warming and urbanization. These global models were then checked on the basis of historic data (changes in ants through time over the last forty years match our predictions based on spatial patterns) and two large-scale experiments. Conversely, in another region, another form of global change, urbanization, led to local change in which ants are where but little change at the level of the whole city. Conspicuous as we did all of this work, however, was that some regions of the world were very poorly understood in terms of insect diversity, including that of ants. We developed a new approach to predict where discoveries of new species and genera are most likely (and then trothed this model with such new discoveries). Finally, we discovered the ways in which global change is likely to alter the role of ants. We documented for the first time the massive extent to which ants help to keep the streets of megacities clean. Each of these projects spawned other projects which have been built upon by students or postdocs who have gone on to become faculty members elsewhere or by collaborators who now lead projects, building upon our data.

Yet, when we talked about this work to the public, the recurrent question we faced was “what should I do about the ants in my kitchen?” It became clear that  we knew far less about the ants that lived in people’s backyards. Scientists, by looking for new species in faraway realms had neglected where we live. In order to better understand the species living near us, we embarked on a citizen science campaign, The School of Ants. This project led to discoveries of the spread of invasive species thousands of miles, updates to the distributions of species across North America, and changes in our understanding of which species are really common. It has also led to new studies of the evolution of invasive ants, based on samples children collected. The success of this project had diverse consequences. It led us to formally evaluate the extent to which children and students learn while participating in the project. It led others to work with us to establish The School of Ants in other countries (Australia, Italy, and Denmark). Finally, it led us to expand into many other citizen science projects in through which we have collectively engaged millions of participants (www.yourwildlife.org). These projects spawned a large endeavor to bring citizen science directly into schools (studentsdiscover.org).
